issue.body:
<!--
    Thank you for contributing!

    ESLint adheres to the [OpenJS Foundation Code of Conduct](https://eslint.org/conduct).
-->

#### Prerequisites checklist

- [x] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/eslint/eslint/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md).

#### What is the purpose of this pull request? (put an "X" next to an item)

<!--
    The following template is intentionally not a markdown checkbox list for the reasons
    explained in https://github.com/eslint/eslint/pull/12848#issuecomment-580302888
-->

[ ] Documentation update
[ ] Bug fix ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/bug-report.md))
[ ] New rule ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/rule-proposal.md))
[ ] Changes an existing rule ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/rule-change-proposal.md))
[ ] Add autofix to a rule
[ ] Add a CLI option
[x] Add something to the core
[ ] Other, please explain:

<!--
    If the item you've checked above has a template, please paste the template questions below and answer them. (If this pull request is addressing an issue, you can just paste a link to the issue here instead.)
-->

<!--
    Please ensure your pull request is ready:

    - Read the pull request guide (https://eslint.org/docs/latest/contribute/pull-requests)
    - Include tests for this change
    - Update documentation for this change (if appropriate)
-->

<!--
    The following is required for all pull requests:
-->

#### What changes did you make? (Give an overview)

This enables serialization of `languageOptions` objects when a `toJSON()` method is present.

fixes #19759

#### Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?

<!-- markdownlint-disable-file MD004 -->

body:
> This would allow language plugin authors to place `toJSON()` on any object that can't be natively serialized

Language plugins would do this in the `normalizeLanguageOptions()` method?

> This leaves users and language plugin authors a bit stuck if they need a function to be passed in.

How would functions be serialized by a custom `.toJSON()`?

> > This would allow language plugin authors to place `toJSON()` on any object that can't be natively serialized
> 
> Language plugins would do this in the `normalizeLanguageOptions()` method?

I hadn't thought of that and that's a good idea! :+1:

> > This leaves users and language plugin authors a bit stuck if they need a function to be passed in.
> 
> How would functions be serialized by a custom `.toJSON()`?

Not the functions, the objects they belong to. So basically, when a value is an object we currently check to see if it has `meta` info, and if so, we don't serialize the object and instead use the name and version (like `parser@1.0.1`). What I'm proposing here is if `meta` is not present, we then check to see if `toJSON()` is present, and if so, call that. Here's the draft PR:
https://github.com/eslint/eslint/pull/19760/files#diff-260c79e7a2f3cfd45a6b348b67610352f644ca1c2abf0ce34c1edaa47019848bR281-R290

> > > This leaves users and language plugin authors a bit stuck if they need a function to be passed in.
> > 
> > 
> > How would functions be serialized by a custom `.toJSON()`?
> 
> Not the functions, the objects they belong to. So basically, when a value is an object we currently check to see if it has `meta` info, and if so, we don't serialize the object and instead use the name and version (like `parser@1.0.1`). What I'm proposing here is if `meta` is not present, we then check to see if `toJSON()` is present, and if so, call that. Here's the draft PR: https://github.com/eslint/eslint/pull/19760/files#diff-260c79e7a2f3cfd45a6b348b67610352f644ca1c2abf0ce34c1edaa47019848bR281-R290

I got it, but how would the custom `toJSON()` handle functions? Would they be just omitted from the output?
Sorry, I see now what's confusing in my question. By custom `toJSON()`, I mean the one language plugins would add on objects, not our `Config#toJSON()`.

> I got it, but how would the custom `toJSON()` handle functions? Would they be just omitted from the output?

That would be up to the language itself to decide. It could just to simply omit functions, or to replace the entire object with a string identifier (like we do when `meta` is present), or convert the function to a boolean, etc. Bottom line: it would be up to the language to attach `toJSON()` with the desired behavior.
